bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to John J. Moran, April 12, 1938

div1.p: Kean describes the 1900 Havana Finlay-Reed dinner, which celebrated the conclusive proof of Finlay's theory by Reed's work. He feels that Finlay has not received a fair share of the credit.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to John J. Moran, April 12, 1938

opener.dateline:
2804 N. Street, N. W.,
WASHINGTON, D. C.
April 12, 1938.

div1.p:
I was interested to get your letter of the 4th, inclosing
the editorial from “EL MUNDO”, “La Gloria de Finlay”. I do not read
Spanish very easily these days but I think I got the sense of it which
was, I think, to urge Cubans to cherish the fame of Finlay as the “Yank-
ess” have done that of Gorgas. I did not get the idea that there was
any effort to diminish the fame of Finlay by claiming his work for
Gorgas, which would be absurd, but only that Finlay was made to suffer
by comparison. I showed your letter to General Ireland who said that
Gorgas never discovered anything, but only carried out the Finlay theory
when it was made a demonstrated fact by Reed.

Many Cubans, as we both know, feel that we in the United
States do not give Finlay his fair share of the credit for this great
discovery, and I feel that there is some truth in this, especially among
those who are not familiar with Finlay's work.

Perhaps you may recall that on December 22nd, 1900, a dinner
was given by 60 of the most prominent doctors of Havana, headed by Dr.
Juan Guiteras, to Dr. Finlay and the Reed Board, to celebrate the con-
clusive demonstration by the Board of the Finlay theory of the trans-
mission of yellow fever by mosquitoes. General Wood was there, Reed and
his two assistants, Gorgas and I. I sat on Dr. Finlay's right. Guiteras
made the principal speech in which he gave the history of Dr. Finlay's
work and that of the Reed Board. He said, as regards the credit to be
given to Finlay and Reed, respectively, he thought it exactly like the
case of the transmission of malaria by the anopheles mosquito. Manson
first gave an authoritative announcement of the mosquito transmission of
malaria and gave good epidemiological reasons to support his theory.
Major Ronald Ross, of the British Medical Service, afterwards made the
laboratory demonstration of Manson's theory, tracing the development of
the malarial parasite in the mosquito after it had bitten a case of mal-
aria, and then its transmission by the bite of the mosquito to another
patient. He said that the scientific world had no difficulty in giving
due credit to each of them, and so it should not be difficult to give due
credit to Finlay and Reed, each for his part. Everyone present, includ-
ing Finlay and Reed, seemed satisfied with this statement of the case, and
I have always upheld it both Americans and Cubans. Ill informed people
in the United States may fail to mention Finlay and ill informed Cubans
may fail to mention Reed, but the fame of each is safe and secure, and I
do not worry over partisan statements. I have just refreshed my memory
of this dinner by reference to my “Diary” and I also read there that on
January 1, 1901, I went to see Moran at the hospital and was happy to find
him out of danger.
Well, you have got me into a long letter.

closer.seg: P. S. You are welcome to tell the story of the Finlay-Reed dinner to any one.
